<div id="siteNotice"><!-- CentralNotice --><!--esi <esi:include src="/esitest-fa8a495983347898/content" /> --> </div>
<div class="mw-indicators">
</div>
<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">History of bitcoin</span></h1>
<div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body">
<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">History of Bitcoin, a cryptocurrency</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg/400px-BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg/600px-BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg/800px-BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="567" data-file-height="319" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BTC_number_of_transactions_per_month.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Number of bitcoin transactions per month (logarithmic scale)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bitcoin" title="Bitcoin">Bitcoin</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrency" title="Cryptocurrency">cryptocurrency</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Digital_asset" title="Digital asset">digital asset</a> that uses <a href="/wiki/Cryptography" title="Cryptography">cryptography</a> to control its creation and management <a href="/wiki/Decentralization" title="Decentralization">rather than relying on central authorities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mercatus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mercatus-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Originally designed as a <a href="/wiki/Medium_of_exchange" title="Medium of exchange">medium of exchange</a>, Bitcoin is now primarily regarded as a <a href="/wiki/Store_of_value" title="Store of value">store of value</a>. The <b>history of bitcoin</b> started with its invention and implementation by <a href="/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto" title="Satoshi Nakamoto">Satoshi Nakamoto</a>, who integrated many existing ideas from the <a href="/wiki/Cryptography" title="Cryptography">cryptography</a> community. Over the course of bitcoin's history, it has undergone rapid growth to become a significant store of value both on- and offline. From the mid-2010s, some businesses began accepting bitcoin in addition to traditional currencies.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Prior to the release of bitcoin, there were a number of digital cash technologies, starting with the issuer-based <a href="/wiki/Ecash" title="Ecash">ecash</a> protocols of <a href="/wiki/David_Chaum" title="David Chaum">David Chaum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Brands" title="Stefan Brands">Stefan Brands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> The idea that solutions to computational puzzles could have some value was first proposed by cryptographers <a href="/wiki/Cynthia_Dwork" title="Cynthia Dwork">Cynthia Dwork</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moni_Naor" title="Moni Naor">Moni Naor</a> in 1992. The idea was independently rediscovered by <a href="/wiki/Adam_Back" title="Adam Back">Adam Back</a> who developed <a href="/wiki/Hashcash" title="Hashcash">hashcash</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Proof-of-work" class="mw-redirect" title="Proof-of-work">proof-of-work</a> scheme for spam control in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> The first proposals for distributed digital scarcity-based <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrencies" class="mw-redirect" title="Cryptocurrencies">cryptocurrencies</a> were <a href="/wiki/Wei_Dai" title="Wei Dai">Wei Dai</a>'s b-money<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Nick_Szabo" title="Nick Szabo">Nick Szabo</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Bit_gold" class="mw-redirect" title="Bit gold">bit gold</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TsoSch2015_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TsoSch2015-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hal_Finney_(cypherpunk)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hal Finney (cypherpunk)">Hal Finney</a> developed <a href="/wiki/Proof_of_work#Reusable_proof-of-work" title="Proof of work">reusable proof of work</a> (RPOW) using hashcash as its proof of work algorithm.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the bit gold proposal which proposed a collectible market-based mechanism for inflation control, <a href="/wiki/Nick_Szabo" title="Nick Szabo">Nick Szabo</a> also investigated some additional aspects including a <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_fault_tolerance" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine fault tolerance">Byzantine fault-tolerant</a> agreement protocol based on quorum addresses to store and transfer the chained <a href="/wiki/Proof-of-work" class="mw-redirect" title="Proof-of-work">proof-of-work</a> solutions, which was vulnerable to Sybil attacks, though.<sup id="cite_ref-TsoSch2015_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TsoSch2015-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Creation">Creation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Creation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>On the 18th of August 2008, the domain name bitcoin.org was registered.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Later that year, on 31 October, a link to a paper authored by <a href="/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto" title="Satoshi Nakamoto">Satoshi Nakamoto</a> titled <i>Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System</i><sup id="cite_ref-whitepaper_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whitepaper-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> was posted to a cryptography mailing list.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> This paper detailed methods of using a <a href="/wiki/Peer-to-peer" title="Peer-to-peer">peer-to-peer</a> network to generate what was described as "a system for electronic transactions without relying on trust".<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> On 3 January 2009, the bitcoin network came into existence with Satoshi Nakamoto mining the <i>genesis block of bitcoin</i> (block number 0), which had a reward of 50 bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Embedded in the genesis block was the text:
</p>
<blockquote><p>The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor on brink of second bailout for banks<sup id="cite_ref-NY2011_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY2011-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The text refers to a headline in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i> published on 3 January 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> This note has been interpreted as both a timestamp of the genesis date and a derisive comment on the instability caused by <a href="/wiki/Fractional-reserve_banking" title="Fractional-reserve banking">fractional-reserve banking</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 18">&#58;&#8202;18&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>The first <a href="/wiki/Open_source" title="Open source">open source</a> bitcoin client was released on 9 January 2009, hosted at <a href="/wiki/SourceForge" title="SourceForge">SourceForge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the first supporters, adopters, contributors to bitcoin and receiver of the first bitcoin transaction was programmer <a href="/wiki/Hal_Finney_(cypherpunk)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hal Finney (cypherpunk)">Hal Finney</a>. Finney downloaded the bitcoin software the day it was released, and received 10 bitcoins from Nakamoto in the world's first bitcoin transaction on 12 January 2009 (bloc 170).<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Other early supporters were Wei Dai, creator of bitcoin predecessor <i>b-money</i>, and <a href="/wiki/Nick_Szabo" title="Nick Szabo">Nick Szabo</a>, creator of bitcoin predecessor <i>bit gold</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early days, Nakamoto is estimated to have mined 1 million bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Before disappearing from any involvement in bitcoin, Nakamoto in a sense handed over the reins to developer <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Andresen" title="Gavin Andresen">Gavin Andresen</a>, who then became the bitcoin lead developer at the <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_Foundation" title="Bitcoin Foundation">Bitcoin Foundation</a>, the 'anarchic' bitcoin community's closest thing to an official public face.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The supply of bitcoin available to be <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_network#Mining" title="Bitcoin network">mined</a> is limited to a maximum 21,000,000 coins by software design. (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://iconicinfonews.com/bitcoin-price-prediction-time-to-buy/">Iconic Info News</a>)
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Satoshi_Nakamoto">Satoshi Nakamoto</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Satoshi Nakamoto">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto" title="Satoshi Nakamoto">Satoshi Nakamoto</a></div>
<p>"Satoshi Nakamoto" is presumed to be a <a href="/wiki/Pseudonym" title="Pseudonym">pseudonym</a> for the person or people who designed the original bitcoin protocol in 2008 and launched the network in 2009. Nakamoto was responsible for creating the majority of the official bitcoin software and was active in making modifications and posting technical information on the bitcoin forum.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> There has been much speculation as to the identity of Satoshi Nakamoto with suspects including Dai, Szabo, and Finney&#160;&#8211;&#32; and accompanying denials.<sup id="cite_ref-LikeInAMirror1_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LikeInAMirror1-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> The possibility that Satoshi Nakamoto was a computer collective in the European financial sector has also been discussed.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Investigations into the real identity of Satoshi Nakamoto were attempted by <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Fast_Company_(magazine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Fast Company (magazine)">Fast Company</a></i>. <i>The New Yorker's</i> investigation brought up at least two possible candidates: Michael Clear and <a href="/wiki/Vili_Lehdonvirta" title="Vili Lehdonvirta">Vili Lehdonvirta</a>. <i>Fast Company'</i>s investigation brought up <a href="/wiki/Circumstantial_evidence" title="Circumstantial evidence">circumstantial evidence</a> linking an <a href="/wiki/Encryption" title="Encryption">encryption</a> <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">patent</a> application filed by Neal King, Vladimir Oksman and Charles Bry on 15 August 2008, and the bitcoin.org domain name which was registered 72&#160;hours later. The patent application (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141219015431/http://bitcoinbettingreview.com/patents/US20100042841.pdf">#20100042841</a>) contained networking and encryption technologies similar to bitcoin's, and <a href="/wiki/Content_analysis" title="Content analysis">textual analysis</a> revealed that the phrase "...&#160;computationally impractical to reverse" appeared in both the patent application and bitcoin's whitepaper.<sup id="cite_ref-whitepaper_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whitepaper-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> All three inventors explicitly denied being Satoshi Nakamoto.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2013, <a href="/wiki/Ted_Nelson" title="Ted Nelson">Ted Nelson</a> speculated that Japanese mathematician <a href="/wiki/Shinichi_Mochizuki" title="Shinichi Mochizuki">Shinichi Mochizuki</a> is Satoshi Nakamoto.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> Later in 2013 the Israeli researchers Dorit Ron and <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shamir" title="Adi Shamir">Adi Shamir</a> pointed to Silk Road-linked <a href="/wiki/Ross_William_Ulbricht" class="mw-redirect" title="Ross William Ulbricht">Ross William Ulbricht</a> as the possible person behind the cover. The two researchers based their suspicion on an analysis of the network of bitcoin transactions.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> These allegations were contested<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> and Ron and Shamir later retracted their claim.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Nakamoto's involvement with bitcoin does not appear to extend past mid-2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> In April 2011, Nakamoto communicated with a bitcoin contributor, saying that he had "moved on to other things".<sup id="cite_ref-NY2011_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY2011-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Stefan Thomas, a Swiss coder and active community member, graphed the time stamps for each of Nakamoto's 500-plus bitcoin forum posts; the resulting chart showed a steep decline to almost no posts between the hours of 5&#160;a.m. and 11&#160;a.m. <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time" title="Greenwich Mean Time">Greenwich Mean Time</a>. Because this pattern held true even on Saturdays and Sundays, it suggested that Nakamoto was asleep at this time, and the hours of 5&#160;a.m. to 11&#160;a.m. GMT are midnight to 6&#160;a.m. <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone" title="Eastern Time Zone">Eastern Standard Time</a> (North American Eastern Standard Time). Other clues suggested that Nakamoto was British: A newspaper headline he had encoded in the genesis block came from the UK-published newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, and both his forum posts and his comments in the bitcoin source code used <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">British English</a> spellings, such as "optimise" and "colour".<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>An Internet search by an anonymous blogger of texts similar in writing to the bitcoin whitepaper suggests <a href="/wiki/Nick_Szabo" title="Nick Szabo">Nick Szabo</a>'s "bit gold" articles as having a similar author.<sup id="cite_ref-LikeInAMirror1_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LikeInAMirror1-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Nick denied being Satoshi, and stated his official opinion on Satoshi and bitcoin in a May 2011 article.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In a March 2014 article in <i><a href="/wiki/Newsweek" title="Newsweek">Newsweek</a>,</i> journalist <a href="/wiki/Leah_McGrath_Goodman" title="Leah McGrath Goodman">Leah McGrath Goodman</a> <a href="/wiki/Doxing" title="Doxing">doxed</a> Dorian S. Nakamoto of <a href="/wiki/Temple_City,_California" title="Temple City, California">Temple City, California</a>, saying that Satoshi Nakamoto is the man's <a href="/wiki/Name_at_birth" class="mw-redirect" title="Name at birth">birth name</a>. Her methods and conclusion drew widespread criticism.<sup id="cite_ref-newsweek_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newsweek-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2016, the <a href="/wiki/London_Review_of_Books" title="London Review of Books">London Review of Books</a> published a piece by <a href="/wiki/Andrew_O%27Hagan" title="Andrew O&#39;Hagan">Andrew O'Hagan</a> about Nakamoto.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After a May 2020 <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> documentary pointed to Adam Back as the creator of bitcoin,<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> widespread discussion ensued. The real identity of Satoshi Nakamoto still remains a matter of dispute.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Growth">Growth</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Growth">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2010">2010</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: 2010">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The first notable retail transaction involving physical goods was paid on May 22, 2010, by exchanging 10,000 mined BTC for two pizzas delivered from a local pizza restaurant in Florida, marking May 22 as the Bitcoin Pizza Day for crypto-fans.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired:RFB_14-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired:RFB-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> At the time, a transaction's value was typically negotiated on the Bitcoin forum.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>On 6 August 2010, a major <a href="/wiki/Vulnerability_(computing)" title="Vulnerability (computing)">vulnerability</a> in the bitcoin protocol was spotted. While the protocol did verify that a transaction's outputs never exceeded its inputs, a transaction whose outputs summed to more than <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle 2^{64}}">
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mn>2</mn>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>64</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle 2^{64}}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ecfb4b886be67f9e99c7fdfecc364be7ba3cc7f9" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:3.039ex; height:2.676ex;" alt="2^{{64}}"/></span> would <a href="/wiki/Integer_overflow" title="Integer overflow">overflow</a>, permitting the transaction author to create arbitrary amounts of bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-Monetarism1_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Monetarism1-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NIST1_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIST1-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> On 15 August, the vulnerability was exploited; a single transaction spent 0.5 bitcoin to send just over 92 billion bitcoins (<span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle 2^{63}}">
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mn>2</mn>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>63</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle 2^{63}}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b39e86ff89473195ea369e15878afc044b87bb06" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:3.039ex; height:2.676ex;" alt="{\displaystyle 2^{63}}"/></span> satoshis) to each of two different addresses on the network. Within hours, the transaction was spotted, the bug was fixed, and the blockchain was forked by miners using an updated version of the bitcoin protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-SourceForge_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SourceForge-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> Since the blockchain was forked below the problematic transaction, the transaction no longer appears in the blockchain used by the Bitcoin network today. This was the only major security flaw found and exploited in bitcoin's history.<sup id="cite_ref-Monetarism1_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Monetarism1-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NIST1_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIST1-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011">2011</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: 2011">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Based on bitcoin's open-source code, other cryptocurrencies started to emerge.<sup id="cite_ref-WsjVolatile_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WsjVolatile-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation" title="Electronic Frontier Foundation">Electronic Frontier Foundation</a>, a non-profit group, started accepting bitcoins in January 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> then stopped accepting them in June 2011, citing concerns about a lack of legal precedent about new currency systems.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> The EFF's decision was reversed on 17 May 2013 when they resumed accepting bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-EFF2013_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EFF2013-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2011, bitcoin payment processor, <a href="/wiki/BitPay" title="BitPay">BitPay</a> was founded to provide mobile checkout services to companies wanting to accept bitcoins as a form of payment.
</p><p>In June 2011, <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> and other organizations began to accept bitcoins for donations.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2012">2012</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 2012">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In January 2012, bitcoin was featured as the main subject within a fictionalized trial on the <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> legal drama <i><a href="/wiki/The_Good_Wife" title="The Good Wife">The Good Wife</a></i> in the third-season episode "<a href="/wiki/The_Good_Wife_(season_3)#Episodes" title="The Good Wife (season 3)">Bitcoin for Dummies</a>". The host of <a href="/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Mad_Money" title="Mad Money">Mad Money</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Cramer" title="Jim Cramer">Jim Cramer</a>, played himself in a courtroom scene where he testifies that he doesn't consider bitcoin a true currency, saying, "There's no central bank to regulate it; it's digital and functions completely peer to peer".<sup id="cite_ref-The_Good_Wife_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Good_Wife-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2012, the Bitcoin Foundation was launched to "accelerate the global growth of bitcoin through standardization, protection, and promotion of the open source protocol". The founders were <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Andresen" title="Gavin Andresen">Gavin Andresen</a>,&#160;Jon Matonis, Patrick Murck,&#160;<a href="/wiki/Charlie_Shrem" title="Charlie Shrem">Charlie Shrem</a>, and&#160;Peter Vessenes.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In October 2012, <a href="/wiki/BitPay" title="BitPay">BitPay</a> reported having over 1,000 merchants accepting bitcoin under its payment processing service.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> In November 2012, <a href="/wiki/WordPress" title="WordPress">WordPress</a> started accepting bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2013">2013</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: 2013">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In February 2013, the bitcoin-based <a href="/wiki/Coinbase" title="Coinbase">payment processor Coinbase</a> reported selling US$1 million worth of bitcoins in a single month at over $22 per bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-$1MBitcoinamonth_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-$1MBitcoinamonth-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Internet_Archive" title="Internet Archive">Internet Archive</a> announced that it was ready to accept donations as bitcoins and that it intends to give employees the option to receive portions of their salaries in bitcoin currency.<sup id="cite_ref-paritynews_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-paritynews-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In March, the bitcoin transaction log, called the <i>blockchain,</i> temporarily split into two independent chains with differing rules on how transactions were accepted. For six hours two bitcoin networks operated at the same time, each with its own version of the transaction history. The core developers called for a temporary halt to transactions, sparking a sharp sell-off.<sup id="cite_ref-bug_events_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bug_events-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Normal operation was restored when the majority of the network downgraded to version 0.7 of the bitcoin software.<sup id="cite_ref-bug_events_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bug_events-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mt._Gox" title="Mt. Gox">Mt. Gox</a> exchange briefly halted bitcoin deposits and the exchange rate briefly dipped by 23% to $37 as the event occurred<sup id="cite_ref-ArsFork_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArsFork-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-VergeFork_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VergeFork-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> before recovering to previous level of approximately $48 in the following hours.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" class="mw-redirect" title="United States of America">US</a>, the <a href="/wiki/FinCEN" class="mw-redirect" title="FinCEN">Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)</a> established regulatory guidelines for "decentralized virtual currencies" such as bitcoin, classifying American bitcoin miners who sell their generated bitcoins as Money Service Businesses (or MSBs), that may be subject to registration and other legal obligations.<sup id="cite_ref-ArsFinCEN_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArsFinCEN-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Finextra1_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finextra1-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FinCEN1_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FinCEN1-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April, payment processors <i>BitInstant</i> and <i>Mt. Gox</i> experienced processing delays due to insufficient capacity<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> resulting in the bitcoin exchange rate dropping from $266 to $76 before returning to $160 within six hours.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> Bitcoin gained greater recognition when services such as <a href="/wiki/OkCupid" title="OkCupid">OkCupid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Foodler" title="Foodler">Foodler</a> began accepting it for payment.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> In April 2013, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Posner" title="Eric Posner">Eric Posner</a>, a law professor at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a>, stated that "a real Ponzi scheme takes fraud; bitcoin, by contrast, seems more like a collective delusion."<sup id="cite_ref-Posner,_Eric_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Posner,_Eric-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 15 May 2013, the US authorities seized accounts associated with Mt. Gox after discovering that it had not registered as a <a href="/wiki/Money_transmitter" title="Money transmitter">money transmitter</a> with FinCEN in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABA_FINCEN_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABA_FINCEN-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 17 May 2013, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/BitInstant" class="mw-redirect" title="BitInstant">BitInstant</a> processed approximately 30 percent of the money going into and out of bitcoin, and in April alone facilitated 30,000 transactions,<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 23 June 2013, it was reported that the US <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">Drug Enforcement Administration</a> listed 11.02 bitcoins as a seized asset in a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">United States Department of Justice</a> seizure notice pursuant to 21 U.S.C. § 881.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> This marked the first time a government agency claimed to have seized bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2013, a project began in Kenya linking bitcoin with <a href="/wiki/M-Pesa" title="M-Pesa">M-Pesa</a>, a popular mobile payments system, in an experiment designed to spur innovative payments in Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> During the same month the Foreign Exchange Administration and Policy Department in Thailand stated that bitcoin lacks any legal framework and would therefore be illegal, which effectively banned trading on bitcoin exchanges in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-telegraph20130730_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-telegraph20130730-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-investvine_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-investvine-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 6 August 2013, Federal Judge Amos Mazzant of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_District_of_Texas" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern District of Texas">Eastern District of Texas</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Circuit" class="mw-redirect" title="Fifth Circuit">Fifth Circuit</a> ruled that bitcoins are "a currency or a form of money" (specifically securities as defined by Federal Securities Laws), and as such were subject to the court's jurisdiction,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> and Germany's Finance Ministry subsumed bitcoins under the term "unit of account"&#160;&#8211;&#32; a financial instrument&#160;&#8211;&#32; though not as e-money or a functional currency, a classification nonetheless having legal and tax implications.<sup id="cite_ref-Marketwatch20130819_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marketwatch20130819-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2013, the FBI seized roughly 26,000&#160;BTC from website <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_(marketplace)" title="Silk Road (marketplace)">Silk Road</a> during the arrest of alleged owner <a href="/wiki/Ross_William_Ulbricht" class="mw-redirect" title="Ross William Ulbricht">Ross William Ulbricht</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Two companies, Robocoin and Bitcoiniacs launched the world's first bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Automated_teller_machine" title="Automated teller machine">ATM</a> on 29 October 2013 in <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Columbia" title="British Columbia">BC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>, allowing clients to sell or purchase bitcoin currency at a downtown coffee shop.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Verge_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Verge-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Chinese internet giant <a href="/wiki/Baidu" title="Baidu">Baidu</a> had allowed clients of website security services to pay with bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2013, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Nicosia" title="University of Nicosia">University of Nicosia</a> announced that it would be accepting bitcoin as payment for tuition fees, with the university's chief financial officer calling it the "gold of tomorrow".<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> During November 2013, the China-based bitcoin exchange <a href="/wiki/BTC_China" class="mw-redirect" title="BTC China">BTC China</a> overtook the Japan-based Mt. Gox and the Europe-based <a href="/wiki/Bitstamp" title="Bitstamp">Bitstamp</a> to become the largest bitcoin trading exchange by trade volume.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2013, <a href="/wiki/Overstock.com" title="Overstock.com">Overstock.com</a><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> announced plans to accept bitcoin in the second half of 2014.
On 5 December 2013, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Bank_of_China" title="People&#39;s Bank of China">People's Bank of China</a> prohibited Chinese financial institutions from using bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-ccontrols_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccontrols-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> After the announcement, the value of bitcoins dropped,<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> and Baidu no longer accepted bitcoins for certain services.<sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg-90">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> Buying real-world goods with any virtual currency had been illegal in China since at least 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 December 2013, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Greenspan" title="Alan Greenspan">Alan Greenspan</a> referred to it as a "bubble".<sup id="cite_ref-Kearns_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kearns-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2014">2014</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: 2014">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In January 2014, <a href="/wiki/Zynga" title="Zynga">Zynga</a><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> announced it was testing bitcoin for purchasing in-game assets in seven of its games. That same month, <a href="/wiki/The_D_Las_Vegas" title="The D Las Vegas">The D Las Vegas</a> Casino Hotel and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Hotel_%26_Casino" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Gate Hotel &amp; Casino">Golden Gate Hotel &amp; Casino</a> properties in downtown Las Vegas announced they would also begin accepting bitcoin, according to an article by <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i>. The article also stated the currency would be accepted in five locations, including the front desk and certain restaurants.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> The network rate exceeded 10 petahash/sec. <a href="/wiki/TigerDirect" title="TigerDirect">TigerDirect</a><sup id="cite_ref-tigger_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tigger-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Overstock.com" title="Overstock.com">Overstock.com</a><sup id="cite_ref-overstock_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overstock-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> started accepting bitcoin.
</p><p>In early February 2014, one of the largest bitcoin exchanges, <a href="/wiki/Mt._Gox" title="Mt. Gox">Mt. Gox</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mtgoxdetails_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtgoxdetails-97">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> suspended withdrawals citing technical issues.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> By the end of the month, Mt. Gox had filed for bankruptcy protection in Japan amid reports that 744,000 bitcoins had been stolen.<sup id="cite_ref-GoxBankrupt_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GoxBankrupt-99">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> Months before the filing, the popularity of Mt. Gox had waned as users experienced difficulties withdrawing funds.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2014, the network exceeded 100 petahash/sec.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> On 18 June 2014, it was announced that bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Payment_service_provider" title="Payment service provider">payment service provider</a> <a href="/wiki/BitPay" title="BitPay">BitPay</a> would become the new sponsor of <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg_Bowl" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Petersburg Bowl">St. Petersburg Bowl</a> under a two-year deal, renamed the Bitcoin St. Petersburg Bowl. Bitcoin was to be accepted for ticket and concession sales at the game as part of the sponsorship, and the sponsorship itself was also paid for using bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-wsj-bitpay_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wsj-bitpay-101">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2014, <a href="/wiki/Newegg" title="Newegg">Newegg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dell" title="Dell">Dell</a><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> started accepting bitcoin.
</p><p>In September 2014, TeraExchange, LLC, received approval from the U.S.<a href="/wiki/Commodity_Futures_Trading_Commission" title="Commodity Futures Trading Commission">Commodity Futures Trading Commission</a> "CFTC" to begin listing an over-the-counter swap product based on the price of a bitcoin. The CFTC swap product approval marks the first time a U.S. regulatory agency approved a bitcoin financial product.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2014, Microsoft began to accept bitcoin to buy Xbox games and Windows software.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, several light-hearted songs celebrating bitcoin such as the "Ode to Satoshi"<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> were released.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A documentary film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rise_and_Rise_of_Bitcoin" title="The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin">The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin</a></i>, was released in 2014, featuring interviews with bitcoin users such as a computer programmer and a drug dealer.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 13 March 2014, <a href="/wiki/Warren_Buffett" title="Warren Buffett">Warren Buffett</a> called bitcoin a "mirage".<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2015">2015</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 2015">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In January 2015, Coinbase raised US$75 million as part of a Series C funding round, smashing the previous record for a bitcoin company. Less than one year after the collapse of Mt. Gox, United Kingdom-based exchange <a href="/wiki/Bitstamp" title="Bitstamp">Bitstamp</a> announced that their exchange would be taken offline while they investigate a hack which resulted in about 19,000 bitcoins (equivalent to roughly US$5 million at that time) being stolen from their hot wallet.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> The exchange remained offline for several days amid speculation that customers had lost their funds. Bitstamp resumed trading on 9 January after increasing security measures and assuring customers that their account balances would not be impacted.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2015, the number of merchants accepting bitcoin exceeded 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-100tmerchants_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100tmerchants-111">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2015, the MAK (<a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Applied_Arts,_Vienna" title="Museum of Applied Arts, Vienna">Museum of Applied Arts, Vienna</a>) became the first museum to acquire art using bitcoin, when it purchased the <a href="/wiki/Screensaver" title="Screensaver">screensaver</a> "Event listeners"<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> of van den Dorpel.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2015, a proposal was submitted to the <a href="/wiki/Unicode_Consortium" title="Unicode Consortium">Unicode Consortium</a> to add a code point for the bitcoin symbol.<sup id="cite_ref-shirriff_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shirriff-114">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2016">2016</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 2016">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In January 2016, the network rate exceeded 1 exahash/sec.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In March 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Japan" title="Cabinet of Japan">Cabinet of Japan</a> recognized virtual currencies like bitcoin as having a function similar to real money.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bidorbuy" title="Bidorbuy">Bidorbuy</a>, the largest South African online marketplace, launched bitcoin payments for both buyers and sellers.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2016, researchers published a paper showing that by November 2013 bitcoin commerce was no longer driven by "sin" activities but instead by legitimate enterprises.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2016, a major bitcoin exchange, <a href="/wiki/Bitfinex" title="Bitfinex">Bitfinex</a>, <a href="/wiki/2016_Bitfinex_hack" title="2016 Bitfinex hack">was hacked</a> and nearly 120,000 BTC (around $60m) was stolen.<sup id="cite_ref-bitfinexheist_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bitfinexheist-118">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2016, the Swiss Railway operator SBB (CFF) upgraded all their automated ticket machines so that bitcoin could be bought from them using the scanner on the ticket machine to scan the bitcoin address on a phone app.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bitcoin generates more academic interest year after year; the number of <a href="/wiki/Google_Scholar" title="Google Scholar">Google Scholar</a> articles published mentioning bitcoin grew from 83 in 2009, to 424 in 2012, and 3580 in 2016. Also, the academic journal <a href="/wiki/Ledger_(journal)" title="Ledger (journal)">Ledger</a> published its first issue. It is edited by Peter Rizun.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2017">2017</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: 2017">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The number of businesses accepting bitcoin continued to increase. In January 2017, <a href="/wiki/NHK" title="NHK">NHK</a> reported the number of online stores accepting bitcoin in Japan had increased 4.6 times over the past year.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> BitPay CEO Stephen Pair declared the company's transaction rate grew 3× from January 2016 to February 2017, and explained usage of bitcoin is growing in B2B supply chain payments.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bitcoin gains more legitimacy among lawmakers and legacy financial companies. For example, Japan passed a law to accept bitcoin as a legal payment method,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> and Russia has announced that it will legalize the use of cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Exchange trading volumes continue to increase. For the 6-month period ending March 2017, Mexican exchange <a href="/wiki/Bitso" title="Bitso">Bitso</a> saw trading volume increase 1500%.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
Between January and May 2017 Poloniex saw an increase of more than 600% active traders online and regularly processed 640% more transactions.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2017, the bitcoin symbol was encoded in <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> version 10.0 at position U+20BF (₿) in the <a href="/wiki/Currency_Symbols_(Unicode_block)" title="Currency Symbols (Unicode block)">Currency Symbols block</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unicode-10_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unicode-10-125">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Up until July 2017, bitcoin users maintained a common set of rules for the cryptocurrency.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-split_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-split-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> On 1 August 2017 bitcoin split into two derivative digital currencies, the bitcoin (BTC) chain with 1 MB blocksize limit and the <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_Cash" title="Bitcoin Cash">Bitcoin Cash</a> (BCH) chain with 8 MB blocksize limit. The split has been called the <i>Bitcoin Cash hard fork</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-split_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-split-127">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 6 December 2017 the software marketplace <a href="/wiki/Steam_(service)" title="Steam (service)">Steam</a> announced that it would no longer accept bitcoin as payment for its products, citing slow transactions speeds, price volatility, and high fees for transactions.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2018">2018</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: 2018">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrency_bubble#2018_crash" title="Cryptocurrency bubble">Cryptocurrency bubble §&#160;2018 crash</a></div>
<p>On 22 January 2018, South Korea brought in a regulation that requires all the bitcoin traders to reveal their identity, thus putting a ban on anonymous trading of bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-TheIndependent_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheIndependent-129">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 24 January 2018, the online payment firm <a href="/wiki/Stripe_(company)" class="mw-redirect" title="Stripe (company)">Stripe</a> announced that it would phase out its support for bitcoin payments by late April 2018, citing declining demand, rising fees and longer transaction times as the reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 25 January 2018, <a href="/wiki/George_Soros" title="George Soros">George Soros</a> referred to bitcoin as a bubble.<sup id="cite_ref-GnMSoros_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GnMSoros-131">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2019">2019</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: 2019">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The dawn of 2019 found Bitcoin trading below the $4000 mark after a difficult year for the global crypto market. It climbed to just over $12,000 in July before.<sup id="cite_ref-in2013dollars.com_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-in2013dollars.com-132">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2020">2020</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: 2020">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On 2 July 2020, the Indian company 69
Shares started to quote a set of bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Exchange-traded_product" title="Exchange-traded product">exchange-traded products</a> (ETP) on the <a href="/wiki/Xetra_(trading_system)" title="Xetra (trading system)">Xetra trading system</a> of the Deutsche Boerse.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 September 2020, the Wiener Börse<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (July 2021)">clarification needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> listed its first 21 titles denominated in cryptocurrencies like bitcoin, including the services of real-time quotation and <a href="/wiki/Settlement_(finance)" title="Settlement (finance)">securities settlement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 September 2020, the <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Stock_Exchange" title="Frankfurt Stock Exchange">Frankfurt Stock Exchange</a> admitted in its Regulated Market the quotation of the first bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Exchange-traded_note" title="Exchange-traded note">exchange-traded note</a> (ETN), centrally cleared via <a href="/wiki/Eurex_Exchange" title="Eurex Exchange">Eurex Clearing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2020, <a href="/wiki/PayPal" title="PayPal">PayPal</a> announced that it would allow its users to buy and sell bitcoin on its platform, although not to deposit or withdraw bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2021">2021</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: 2021">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>From February 2021, the Swiss canton of <a href="/wiki/Zug" title="Zug">Zug</a> allows for tax payments in bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 June 2021, <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a> President <a href="/wiki/Nayib_Bukele" title="Nayib Bukele">Nayib Bukele</a> announced his plans to adopt bitcoin as <a href="/wiki/Legal_tender" title="Legal tender">legal tender</a>; this would render El Salvador the world's first country to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 8 June 2021, at the initiative of the president, pro-government deputies in the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_El_Salvador" title="Legislative Assembly of El Salvador">Legislative Assembly of El Salvador</a> voted legislation—<i>Ley Bitcoin</i> or the <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_Law" title="Bitcoin Law">Bitcoin Law</a>—to make Bitcoin legal tender in the country alongside the <a href="/wiki/US_Dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="US Dollar">US Dollar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ft_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ft-141">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2022">2022</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: 2022">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Global economic factors that stemmed from <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russia's War in Ukraine</a> negatively affected the price of Bitcoin. On April 22, 2022, its price fell back down below $40,000.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> It further dropped to as low as $26,970 in May after the collapse of <a href="/wiki/Terra_(blockchain)" title="Terra (blockchain)">Terra-Luna</a> and its sister stablecoin, UST, in addition to a shedding of tech stocks.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> On 18 June, Bitcoin dropped below $18,000, to trade at levels beneath its 2017 highs.<sup id="cite_ref-barronsjun22_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barronsjun22-144">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-june22FT_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-june22FT-145">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> In the aftermath of the collapse of <a href="/wiki/FTX_(company)" class="mw-redirect" title="FTX (company)">FTX (company)</a> Bitcoin's price has dropped furthermore.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Prices_and_value_history">Prices and value history</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Prices and value history">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:452px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_(Bitstamp,_Mt._Gox).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png/450px-BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png" decoding="async" width="450" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png/675px-BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png/900px-BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_%28Bitstamp%2C_Mt._Gox%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1056" data-file-height="319" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BitCoin-USDollar_2011-19_(Bitstamp,_Mt._Gox).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The price of a bitcoin reached US$1,139.9 on 4 January 2017. (<a href="/wiki/Semi-log_plot" title="Semi-log plot">semi logarithmic plot</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Among the factors which may have contributed to this rise were the <a href="/wiki/European_sovereign-debt_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="European sovereign-debt crisis">European sovereign-debt crisis</a>&#160;&#8211;&#32;particularly the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%932013_Cypriot_financial_crisis" title="2012–2013 Cypriot financial crisis">2012–2013 Cypriot financial crisis</a>&#160;&#8211;&#32;statements by FinCEN improving the currency's legal standing, and rising media and Internet interest.<sup id="cite_ref-NewYorker1_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewYorker1-147">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NewYorker2_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewYorker2-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Quartz1_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Quartz1-149">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Economist1_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist1-150">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Until 2013, almost all market with bitcoins were in United States dollars (US$).<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As the market valuation of the total stock of bitcoins approached US$1 billion, some commentators called bitcoin prices a <a href="/wiki/Economic_bubble" title="Economic bubble">bubble</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Atlantic1_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic1-154">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FelixSalmon1_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FelixSalmon1-155">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ArtCashin1_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArtCashin1-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> In early April 2013, the price per bitcoin dropped from $266 to around $50 and then rose to around $100. Over two weeks starting late June 2013 the price dropped steadily to $70. The price began to recover, peaking once again on 1 October at $140. On 2 October, <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_(marketplace)" title="Silk Road (marketplace)">The Silk Road</a> was seized by the <a href="/wiki/FBI" class="mw-redirect" title="FBI">FBI</a>. This <a href="/wiki/Ross_Ulbricht" title="Ross Ulbricht">seizure</a> caused a flash crash to $110. The price quickly rebounded, returning to $200 several weeks later.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> The latest run went from $200 on 3 November to $900 on 18 November.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> Bitcoin passed US$1,000 on 28 November 2013 at Mt. Gox.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<caption>Bitcoin value history (comparison to US$)
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th width="20%">Date
</th>
<th width="10%">USD&#160;: 1 BTC
</th>
<th class="unsortable">Notes
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td data-sort-value="2009-01">Jan 2009&#160;– Mar 2010
</td>
<td data-sort-value="0.000001">basically nothing
</td>
<td>No exchanges or market; users were mainly cryptography fans who were sending bitcoins for hobby purposes representing low or no value. In March 2010, user "SmokeTooMuch" auctioned 10,000 BTC for $50 (cumulatively), but no buyer was found.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td data-sort-value="2010-02">May 2010
</td>
<td data-sort-value="0.001">less than $0.01
</td>
<td>On 22 May 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> Laszlo Hanyecz made the first real-world transaction by buying two pizzas in <a href="/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida" title="Jacksonville, Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a>, for 10,000 BTC, an amount that would surpass $600 million if held in April 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td data-sort-value="2011-02">Feb 2011&#160;– April 2011

</td>

<td>19 May 2021
</td>
<td>$30,000 <img alt="Decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" />
</td>
<td>Bitcoin price drops to $30,000 at one point following suggestions that Tesla has sold or will sell its Bitcoin holdings<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> and a new set of regulations from the Chinese government to support their cryptocurrency crackdown.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>

</td>

</td></tr>
