Bitcoin sunk to a two-year low.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Forks">Forks</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Forks">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_scalability_problem" title="Bitcoin scalability problem">Bitcoin scalability problem</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_bitcoin_forks" title="List of bitcoin forks">List of bitcoin forks</a></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Fork_(blockchain)" title="Fork (blockchain)">fork</a>, referring to a blockchain, is defined variously as a blockchain split into two paths forward, or as a change of protocol rules. Accidental forks on the bitcoin network regularly occur as part of the mining process. They happen when two miners find a block at a similar point in time. As a result, the network briefly forks. This fork is subsequently resolved by the software which automatically chooses the longest chain, thereby orphaning the extra blocks added to the shorter chain (that were dropped by the longer chain).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="March_2013">March 2013</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: March 2013">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On 12 March 2013, a bitcoin miner running version 0.8.0 of the bitcoin software created a large block that was considered invalid in version 0.7 (due to an undiscovered inconsistency between the two versions).
This created a split or "fork" in the blockchain since computers with the recent version of the software accepted the invalid block and continued to build on the diverging chain, whereas older versions of the software rejected it and continued extending the blockchain without the offending block.
This split resulted in two separate transaction logs being formed without clear consensus, which allowed for the same funds to be spent differently on each chain. In response, the Mt. Gox exchange temporarily halted bitcoin deposits.<sup id="cite_ref-Mtgoxforkchain_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mtgoxforkchain-200">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> The exchange rate fell 23% to $37 on the Mt. Gox exchange but rose most of the way back to its prior level of $48.<sup id="cite_ref-ArsFork_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArsFork-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-VergeFork_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VergeFork-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Miners resolved the split by downgrading to version 0.7, putting them back on track with the canonical blockchain.
User funds largely remained unaffected and were available when network consensus was restored.<sup id="cite_ref-ChainFork1_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChainFork1-201">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup> The network reached consensus and continued to operate as normal a few hours after the split.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="August_2017">August 2017</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: August 2017">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Two significant forks took place in August. One, <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_Cash" title="Bitcoin Cash">Bitcoin Cash</a>, is a hard fork off the main chain in opposition to the other, which is a soft fork to implement <a href="/wiki/Segregated_Witness" class="mw-redirect" title="Segregated Witness">Segregated Witness</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Regulatory_issues">Regulatory issues</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Regulatory issues">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>On 18 March 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Financial_Crimes_Enforcement_Network" title="Financial Crimes Enforcement Network">Financial Crimes Enforcement Network</a> (or FinCEN), a bureau of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">United States Department of the Treasury</a>, issued a report regarding <a href="/wiki/Centralized" class="mw-redirect" title="Centralized">centralized</a> and decentralized "virtual currencies" and their legal status within "<a href="/wiki/Money_services_business" title="Money services business">money services business</a>" (MSB) and <a href="/wiki/Bank_Secrecy_Act" title="Bank Secrecy Act">Bank Secrecy Act</a> regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-FinCEN1_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FinCEN1-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABA_FINCEN_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABA_FINCEN-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> It classified digital currencies and other digital payment systems such as bitcoin as "<a href="/wiki/Virtual_currency" title="Virtual currency">virtual currencies</a>" because they are not <a href="/wiki/Legal_tender" title="Legal tender">legal tender</a> under any sovereign <a href="/wiki/Jurisdiction_(area)" title="Jurisdiction (area)">jurisdiction</a>. FinCEN cleared American users of bitcoin of legal obligations<sup id="cite_ref-ABA_FINCEN_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABA_FINCEN-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> by saying, "A user of virtual currency is not an MSB under FinCEN's regulations and therefore is not subject to MSB registration, reporting, and recordkeeping regulations." However, it held that American entities who generate "virtual currency" such as bitcoins are money transmitters or MSBs if they sell their generated currency for <a href="/wiki/National_currency" class="mw-redirect" title="National currency">national currency</a>: "...a person that creates units of convertible virtual currency and sells those units to another person for real currency or its equivalent is engaged in transmission to another location and is a money transmitter." This specifically extends to "miners" of the bitcoin currency who may have to register as MSBs and abide by the legal requirements of being a money transmitter if they sell their generated bitcoins for <a href="/wiki/National_currency" class="mw-redirect" title="National currency">national currency</a> and are within the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-ArsFinCEN_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArsFinCEN-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Since FinCEN issued this guidance, dozens of virtual currency exchangers and administrators have registered with FinCEN, and FinCEN is receiving an increasing number of <a href="/wiki/Suspicious_activity_report" title="Suspicious activity report">suspicious activity reports</a> (SARs) from these entities.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, FinCEN claimed regulation over American entities that manage bitcoins in a <a href="/wiki/Payment_processor" title="Payment processor">payment processor</a> setting or as an exchanger: "In addition, a person is an exchanger and a money transmitter if the person accepts such de-centralized convertible virtual currency from one person and transmits it to another person as part of the acceptance and transfer of currency, funds, or other value that substitutes for currency."<sup id="cite_ref-Finextra1_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finextra1-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FinCEN1_61-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FinCEN1-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In summary, FinCEN's decision would require bitcoin exchanges where bitcoins are traded for traditional currencies to disclose large transactions and suspicious activity, comply with <a href="/wiki/Money_laundering" title="Money laundering">money laundering</a> regulations, and collect information about their customers as traditional <a href="/wiki/Financial_institutions" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial institutions">financial institutions</a> are required to do.<sup id="cite_ref-ABA_FINCEN_67-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABA_FINCEN-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forbes1_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes1-204">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JapanTimes_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JapanTimes-205">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Jennifer Shasky Calvery, the director of FinCEN said, "Virtual currencies are subject to the same rules as other currencies. ... Basic money-services business rules apply here."<sup id="cite_ref-ABA_FINCEN_67-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABA_FINCEN-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In its October 2012 study, <i>Virtual currency schemes</i>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> concluded that the growth of virtual currencies will continue, and, given the currencies' inherent price instability, lack of close regulation, and risk of illegal uses by anonymous users, the Bank warned that periodic examination of developments would be necessary to reassess risks.<sup id="cite_ref-ECBank201210_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECBank201210-206">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the U.S. Treasury extended its anti-money laundering regulations to processors of bitcoin transactions.<sup id="cite_ref-foxnews1_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foxnews1-207">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2013, Bitcoin Foundation board member Jon Matonis wrote in <i>Forbes</i> that he received a warning letter from the <a href="/wiki/California_Department_of_Financial_Institutions" title="California Department of Financial Institutions">California Department of Financial Institutions</a> accusing the foundation of unlicensed money transmission. Matonis denied that the foundation is engaged in money transmission and said he viewed the case as "an opportunity to educate state regulators."<sup id="cite_ref-NBCnews20130624_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NBCnews20130624-209">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In late July 2013, the industry group Committee for the Establishment of the Digital Asset Transfer Authority began to form to set best practices and standards, to work with regulators and policymakers to adapt existing currency requirements to digital currency technology and business models and develop risk management standards.<sup id="cite_ref-WashPost20130730_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WashPost20130730-210">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission</a> filed an administrative action against Erik T. Voorhees, for violating Securities Act Section 5 for publicly offering unregistered interests in two bitcoin websites in exchange for bitcoins.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By December 2017, bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures contracts</a> began to be offered, and the US <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Board_Options_Exchange" title="Chicago Board Options Exchange">Chicago Board Options Exchange</a> (CBOE) was formally settling the futures daily.<sup id="cite_ref-fortune20171212_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune20171212-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg20171209_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg20171209-213">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>
By 2019, multiple trading companies were offering services around bitcoin futures.<sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg20190909_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg20190909-214">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bitcoin_faucets">Bitcoin faucets</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Bitcoin faucets">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Bitcoin_faucet"></span>
A <i>bitcoin faucet</i> is a reward system, in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Website" title="Website">website</a> or <a href="/wiki/Application_software" title="Application software">software app</a>, that dispenses rewards in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin#Units_and_divisibility" title="Bitcoin">satoshi</a>, which is worth a hundredth of a millionth BTC, for visitors to claim in exchange for completing a <a href="/wiki/Captcha" class="mw-redirect" title="Captcha">captcha</a> or task as described by the website. There are also faucets that dispense alternative <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrency" title="Cryptocurrency">cryptocurrencies</a>. The first bitcoin faucet was called "The Bitcoin Faucet" and was developed by <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Andresen" title="Gavin Andresen">Gavin Andresen</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> It originally gave out five bitcoins per person.
</p><p>The rewards are dispensed at various predetermined intervals of time as rewards for completing simple tasks such as captcha completion and as prizes from simple games. Faucets usually give fractions of a bitcoin, but the amount will typically fluctuate according to the value of bitcoin. Some faucets also have random larger rewards. To reduce <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_mining" class="mw-redirect" title="Bitcoin mining">mining fees</a>, faucets normally save up these small individual payments in their own <a href="/wiki/Ledger" title="Ledger">ledgers</a>, which then add up to make a larger payment that is sent to a user's <a href="/wiki/Bitcoin_network#Bitcoin_addresses" title="Bitcoin network">bitcoin address</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Because bitcoin transactions are irreversible and there are many faucets, they have become targets for hackers interested in stealing bitcoins. Advertisements are the main income source of bitcoin faucets. Faucets try to get traffic from users by offering free bitcoin as an incentive. Some ad networks also pay directly in bitcoin. This means that faucets often have a low profit margin. Some faucets also make money by mining <a href="/wiki/Altcoin" class="mw-redirect" title="Altcoin">altcoins</a> in the background, using the user's CPU.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Theft_and_exchange_shutdowns">Theft and exchange shutdowns</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Theft and exchange shutdowns">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bitcoins can be stored in a bitcoin <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrency_wallet" title="Cryptocurrency wallet">cryptocurrency wallet</a>. Theft of bitcoin has been documented on numerous occasions. At other times, bitcoin exchanges have shut down, taking their clients' bitcoins with them. A <i>Wired</i> study published April 2013 showed that 45 percent of bitcoin exchanges end up closing.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired.co.UK_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired.co.UK-217">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 19 June 2011, a security breach of the <a href="/wiki/Mt._Gox" title="Mt. Gox">Mt. Gox</a> bitcoin exchange caused the nominal price of a bitcoin to fraudulently drop to one cent on the Mt. Gox exchange, after a hacker used credentials from a Mt. Gox auditor's compromised computer illegally to transfer a large number of bitcoins to himself. They used the exchange's software to sell them all nominally, creating a massive "ask" order at any price. Within minutes, the price reverted to its correct user-traded value.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mick_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mick-220">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-register1_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-register1-223">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> Accounts with the equivalent of more than US$8,750,000 were affected.<sup id="cite_ref-mick_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mick-220">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2011, the operator of Bitomat, the third-largest bitcoin exchange, announced that he had lost access to his wallet.dat file with about 17,000 bitcoins (roughly equivalent to US$220,000 at that time). He announced that he would sell the service for the missing amount, aiming to use funds from the sale to refund his customers.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2011, MyBitcoin, a now defunct bitcoin transaction processor, declared that it was hacked, which caused it to be shut down, paying 49% on customer deposits, leaving more than 78,000 bitcoins (equivalent to roughly US$800,000 at that time) unaccounted for.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In early August 2012, a lawsuit was filed in <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> court against Bitcoinica&#160;&#8211;&#32; a bitcoin trading venue&#160;&#8211;&#32; claiming about US$460,000 from the company. Bitcoinica was hacked twice in 2012, which led to allegations that the venue neglected the safety of customers' money and cheated them out of withdrawal requests.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In late August 2012, an operation titled Bitcoin Savings and Trust was shut down by the owner, leaving around US$5.6 million in bitcoin-based debts; this led to allegations that the operation was a <a href="/wiki/Ponzi_scheme" title="Ponzi scheme">Ponzi scheme</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> In September 2012, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission</a> had reportedly started an investigation on the case.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2012, Bitfloor, a bitcoin exchange, also reported being hacked, with 24,000 bitcoins (worth about US$250,000) stolen. As a result, Bitfloor suspended operations.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> The same month, Bitfloor resumed operations; its founder said that he reported the theft to FBI, and that he plans to repay the victims, though the time frame for repayment is unclear.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 April 2013, Instawallet, a web-based wallet provider, was hacked,<sup id="cite_ref-cutler13insta_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cutler13insta-236">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> resulting in the theft of over 35,000 bitcoins<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> which were valued at US$129.90 per bitcoin at the time, or nearly $4.6 million in total. As a result, Instawallet suspended operations.<sup id="cite_ref-cutler13insta_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cutler13insta-236">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 August 2013, the Bitcoin Foundation announced that a bug in a <a href="/wiki/Pseudorandom_number_generator" title="Pseudorandom number generator">pseudorandom number generator</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">Android operating system</a> had been exploited to steal from wallets generated by Android apps; fixes were provided 13 August 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-TheRegister20130812_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheRegister20130812-238">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2013, Inputs.io, an Australian-based bitcoin wallet provider was hacked with a loss of 4100 bitcoins, worth over A$1 million at time of theft. The service was run by the operator TradeFortress. Coinchat, the associated bitcoin chat room, was taken over by a new admin.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 26 October 2013, a Hong Kong–based bitcoin trading platform owned by Global Bond Limited (GBL) vanished with 30 million yuan (US$5 million) from 500 investors.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mt._Gox" title="Mt. Gox">Mt. Gox</a>, the Japan-based exchange that in 2013 handled 70% of all worldwide bitcoin traffic, declared bankruptcy in February 2014, with bitcoins worth about $390 million missing, for unclear reasons. The CEO was eventually arrested and charged with embezzlement.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 March 2014, Flexcoin announced it was closing its doors because of a hack attack that took place the day before.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> In a statement that once occupied <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://flexcoin.com/">their homepage</a>, they announced on 3 March 2014 that "As Flexcoin does not have the resources, assets, or otherwise to come back from this loss [the hack], we are closing our doors immediately."<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> Users can no longer log into the site.
</p><p>Chinese cryptocurrency exchange Bter lost $2.1 million in BTC in February 2015.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenian</a> exchange <a href="/wiki/Bitstamp" title="Bitstamp">Bitstamp</a> lost bitcoin worth $5.1 million to a hack in January 2015.
</p><p>The US-based exchange Cryptsy declared bankruptcy in January 2016, ostensibly because of a 2014 hacking incident; the court-appointed receiver later alleged that Cryptsy's CEO had stolen $3.3 million.
</p><p>In August 2016, hackers stole some $72 million in customer bitcoin from the Hong Kong–based exchange <a href="/wiki/Bitfinex" title="Bitfinex">Bitfinex</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2017, hackers stole 4,700 bitcoins from NiceHash, a platform that allowed users to sell hashing power.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The value of the stolen bitcoins totaled about $80 million at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 19 December 2017, Yapian, a company that owns the Youbit cryptocurrency exchange in South Korea, filed for bankruptcy following a hack, the second in eight months.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 November 2022 <a href="/wiki/FTX_(company)" class="mw-redirect" title="FTX (company)">FTX</a> filed for <a href="/wiki/FTX_(company)#November_2022_crisis_and_bankruptcy" class="mw-redirect" title="FTX (company)">bankruptcy</a> with an estimated $8 billion missing in customer funds.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxation_and_regulation">Taxation and regulation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Taxation and regulation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Legality_of_bitcoin_by_country_or_territory" class="mw-redirect" title="Legality of bitcoin by country or territory">Legality of bitcoin by country or territory</a></div>
<p>In 2012, the Cryptocurrency Legal Advocacy Group (CLAG) stressed the importance for taxpayers to determine whether taxes are due on a bitcoin-related transaction based on whether one has experienced a "<a href="/wiki/Revenue_recognition" title="Revenue recognition">realization</a> event": when a taxpayer has provided a service in exchange for bitcoins, a realization event has probably occurred and any gain or loss would likely be calculated using fair market values for the service provided."<sup id="cite_ref-BitCoin_Tax_issues_Oct_2012_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BitCoin_Tax_issues_Oct_2012-250">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2013, the German Finance Ministry characterized bitcoin as a <a href="/wiki/Unit_of_account" title="Unit of account">unit of account</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Marketwatch20130819_77-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marketwatch20130819-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FAZ20130816_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAZ20130816-251">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> usable in <a href="/wiki/Clearing_house_(finance)" title="Clearing house (finance)">multilateral clearing circles</a> and subject to capital gains tax if held less than one year.<sup id="cite_ref-FAZ20130816_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAZ20130816-251">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 5 December 2013, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Bank_of_China" title="People&#39;s Bank of China">People's Bank of China</a> announced in a press release regarding bitcoin regulation that whilst individuals in China are permitted to freely trade and exchange bitcoins as a commodity, it is prohibited for Chinese financial banks to operate using bitcoins or for bitcoins to be used as legal tender currency, and that entities dealing with bitcoins must track and report suspicious activity to prevent money laundering.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> The value of bitcoin dropped on various exchanges between 11 and 20 percent following the regulation announcement, before rebounding upward again.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Arbitrary_blockchain_content">Arbitrary blockchain content</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Arbitrary blockchain content">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bitcoin's blockchain can be loaded with arbitrary data. In 2018 researchers from <a href="/wiki/RWTH_Aachen_University" title="RWTH Aachen University">RWTH Aachen University and Goethe University</a> identified 1,600 files added to the blockchain, 59 of which included links to unlawful images of child exploitation, politically sensitive content, or privacy violations. "Our analysis shows that certain content, e.g. illegal pornography, can render the mere possession of a blockchain illegal."<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a> also sent out an alert in 2015 saying that "the design of the blockchain means there is the possibility of malware being injected and permanently hosted with no methods currently available to wipe this data".<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_bitcoin&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-mercatus-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-mercatus_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite id="CITEREFJerry_BritoAndrea_Castillo2013" class="citation web cs1">Jerry Brito; <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3047875">A History of Bitcoin.</a> <i>Monetary Economics: International Financial Flows, Financial Crises, Regulation &amp; Supervision eJournal</i>. Social Science Research Network (SSRN). Accessed 8 January 2018.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFChaum1983" class="citation journal cs1">Chaum, David (1983). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hit.bme.hu/~buttyan/courses/BMEVIHIM219/2009/Chaum.BlindSigForPayment.1982.PDF">"Blind signatures for untraceable payments"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Advances in Cryptology Proceedings of Crypto</i>. <b>82</b> (3): 199–203. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2F978-1-4757-0602-4_18">10.1007/978-1-4757-0602-4_18</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4757-0604-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4757-0604-8"><bdi>978-1-4757-0604-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Cryptology+Proceedings+of+Crypto&amp;rft.atitle=Blind+signatures+for+untraceable+payments&amp;rft.volume=82&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=199-203&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2F978-1-4757-0602-4_18&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4757-0604-8&amp;rft.aulast=Chaum&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hit.bme.hu%2F~buttyan%2Fcourses%2FBMEVIHIM219%2F2009%2FChaum.BlindSigForPayment.1982.PDF&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFChaumFiatNaor" class="citation journal cs1">Chaum, David; Fiat, Amos; Naor, Moni. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://blog.koehntopp.de/uploads/chaum_fiat_naor_ecash.pdf">"Untraceable Electronic Cash"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Lecture Notes in Computer Science</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Lecture+Notes+in+Computer+Science&amp;rft.atitle=Untraceable+Electronic+Cash&amp;rft.aulast=Chaum&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.au=Fiat%2C+Amos&amp;rft.au=Naor%2C+Moni&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fblog.koehntopp.de%2Fuploads%2Fchaum_fiat_naor_ecash.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFChaumBrands1999" class="citation news cs1">Chaum, David; Brands, Stefan (4 January 1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://spectrum.ieee.org/computing/software/minting-electronic-cash">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>'Minting' electronic cash"</a>. <i>IEEE Spectrum special issue on electronic money, February 1997</i>. IEEE<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFNarayananBonneauFeltenMiller2016" class="citation book cs1">Narayanan, Arvind; Bonneau, Joseph; Felten, Edward; Miller, Andrew; Goldfeder, Steven (2016). <i>Bitcoin and Cryptocurrency Technologies: A Comprehensive Introduction</i>. Princeton and Oxford: Princeton University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-691-17169-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-691-17169-2"><bdi>978-0-691-17169-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bitcoin+and+Cryptocurrency+Technologies%3A+A+Comprehensive+Introduction&amp;rft.place=Princeton+and+Oxford&amp;rft.pub=Princeton+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-691-17169-2&amp;rft.aulast=Narayanan&amp;rft.aufirst=Arvind&amp;rft.au=Bonneau%2C+Joseph&amp;rft.au=Felten%2C+Edward&amp;rft.au=Miller%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.au=Goldfeder%2C+Steven&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFDai1998" class="citation web cs1">Dai, W (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.weidai.com/bmoney.txt">"b-money"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111105071114/http://www.weidai.com/bmoney.txt">Archived</a> from the original on 5 November 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 December</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=b-money&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.aulast=Dai&amp;rft.aufirst=W&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.weidai.com%2Fbmoney.txt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFSzabo2008" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Nick_Szabo" title="Nick Szabo">Szabo, Nick</a> (27 December 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unenumerated.blogspot.com/2005/12/bit-gold.html">"Bit Gold"</a>. <i>Unenumerated</i>. Blogspot. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110922000422/http://unenumerated.blogspot.com/2005/12/bit-gold.html">Archived</a> from the original on 22 September 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 December</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Unenumerated&amp;rft.atitle=Bit+Gold&amp;rft.date=2008-12-27&amp;rft.aulast=Szabo&amp;rft.aufirst=Nick&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Funenumerated.blogspot.com%2F2005%2F12%2Fbit-gold.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-TsoSch2015-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-TsoSch2015_9-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-TsoSch2015_9-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFTsorschScheuermann2015" class="citation web cs1">Tsorsch, Florian; Scheuermann, Bjorn (15 May 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eprint.iacr.org/2015/464.pdf">"Bitcoin and Beyond: A Technical Survey of Decentralized Digital Currencies"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFPeterson2014" class="citation news cs1">Peterson, Andrea (3 January 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2014/01/03/hal-finney-received-the-first-bitcoin-transaction-heres-how-he-describes-it/">"Hal Finney received the first Bitcoin transaction. <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFPopper2014" class="citation news cs1">Popper, Nathaniel (30 August 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/31/business/hal-finney-cryptographer-and-bitcoin-pioneer-dies-at-58.html?_r=1">"Hal Finney, Cryptographer and Bitcoin Pioneer, Dies at 58"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFNaeem" class="citation news cs1">Naeem, Hassan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.serviceisonline.com/who-owns-the-worlds-biggest-bitcoin-wallet/">"Who Owns the World's Biggest Bitcoin Wallet?"</a>. <i>Service is Online</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 February</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Service+is+Online&amp;rft.atitle=Who+Owns+the+World%27s+Biggest+Bitcoin+Wallet%3F&amp;rft.aulast=Naeem&amp;rft.aufirst=Hassan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.serviceisonline.com%2Fwho-owns-the-worlds-biggest-bitcoin-wallet%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFBosker2013" class="citation news cs1">Bosker, Bianca (16 April 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/16/gavin-andresen-bitcoin_n_3093316.html">"Gavin Andresen, Bitcoin Architect: Meet The Man Bringing You Bitcoin (And Getting Paid In It)"</a>. <i>The Huffington Post</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-newsweek-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-newsweek_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFLeah_McGrath_Goodman2014" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Leah_McGrath_Goodman" title="Leah McGrath Goodman">Leah McGrath Goodman</a> (6 March 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://mag.newsweek.com/2014/03/14/bitcoin-satoshi-nakamoto.html">"The Face Behind Bitcoin"</a>. <i>Newsweek</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140308010837/http://mag.newsweek.com/2014/03/14/bitcoin-satoshi-nakamoto.html">Archived</a> from the original on 8 March 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFGreenberg2014" class="citation news cs1">Greenberg, Andy (6 March 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2014/03/06/bitcoin-community-responds-to-satoshi-nakamotos-outing-with-disbelief-anger-fascination/">"Bitcoin Community Responds To Satoshi Nakamoto's 'Uncovering' With Disbelief, Anger, Fascination"</a>. <i>Forbes.com</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140307190253/http://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2014/03/06/bitcoin-community-responds-to-satoshi-nakamotos-outing-with-disbelief-anger-fascination/">Archived</a> from the original on 7 March 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFNakamoto2016" class="citation journal cs1">Nakamoto, Andrew O’Hagan on the many lives of Satoshi (30 June 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n13/andrew-ohagan/the-satoshi-affair">"The Satoshi Affair"</a>. <i>London Review of Books</i>. <b>38</b> (13): 7–28<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-02/latest-satoshi-nakamoto-candidate-buying-bitcoin-no-matter-what">"Latest Satoshi Nakamoto Candidate Buying Bitcoin No Matter What"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a></i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg+News&amp;rft.atitle=Latest+Satoshi+Nakamoto+Candidate+Buying+Bitcoin+No+Matter+What&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2020-06-02%2Flatest-satoshi-nakamoto-candidate-buying-bitcoin-no-matter-what&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Monetarism1-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Monetarism1_41-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Monetarism1_41-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFSawyer2013" class="citation web cs1">Sawyer, Matt (26 February 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140409025103/http://www.monetarism.co.uk/the-beginners-guide-to-bitcoin-everything-you-need-to-know/">"The Beginners Guide To Bitcoin&#160;– Everything You Need To Know"</a>. Monetarism. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.monetarism.co.uk/the-beginners-guide-to-bitcoin-everything-you-need-to-know/">the original</a> on 9 April 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 November</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Beginners+Guide+To+Bitcoin+%E2%80%93+Everything+You+Need+To+Know&amp;rft.pub=Monetarism&amp;rft.date=2013-02-26&amp;rft.aulast=Sawyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Matt&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.monetarism.co.uk%2Fthe-beginners-guide-to-bitcoin-everything-you-need-to-know%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-NIST1-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-NIST1_42-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NIST1_42-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-5139">"Vulnerability Summary for CVE-2010-5139"</a>. <li id="cite_note-bug_events-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-bug_events_55-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-bug_events_55-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFLee2013" class="citation web cs1">Lee, Timothy (11 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://arstechnica.com/business/2013/03/major-glitch-in-bitcoin-network-sparks-sell-off-price-temporarily-falls-23/">"Major glitch in Bitcoin network sparks sell-off; price temporarily falls 23%"</a>. arstechnica.com<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 February</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Major+glitch+in+Bitcoin+network+sparks+sell-off%3B+price+temporarily+falls+23%25&amp;rft.pub=arstechnica.com&amp;rft.date=2013-03-11&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Timothy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farstechnica.com%2Fbusiness%2F2013%2F03%2Fmajor-glitch-in-bitcoin-network-sparks-sell-off-price-temporarily-falls-23%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ArsFork-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ArsFork_56-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ArsFork_56-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFLee2013" class="citation web cs1">Lee, Timothy (12 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://arstechnica.com/business/2013/03/major-glitch-in-bitcoin-network-sparks-sell-off-price-temporarily-falls-23/">"Major glitch in Bitcoin network sparks sell-off; price temporarily falls 23%"</a>. Ars Technica. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130420050926/http://arstechnica.com/business/2013/03/major-glitch-in-bitcoin-network-sparks-sell-off-price-temporarily-falls-23/">Archived</a> from the original on 20 April 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-VergeFork-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-VergeFork_57-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-VergeFork_57-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFBlagdon2013" class="citation web cs1">Blagdon, Jeff (12 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theverge.com/2013/3/12/4092898/technical-problems-cause-bitcoin-to-plummet-from-record-high">"Technical problems cause Bitcoin to plummet from record high, Mt. Gox suspends deposits"</a>. <li id="cite_note-ArsFinCEN-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ArsFinCEN_59-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ArsFinCEN_59-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFLee2013" class="citation web cs1">Lee, Timothy (20 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/03/us-regulator-bitcoin-exchanges-must-comply-with-money-laundering-laws/">"US regulator Bitcoin Exchanges Must Comply With Money Laundering Laws"</a>. <li id="cite_note-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-70">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=es&amp;tl=en&amp;js=n&amp;prev=_t&amp;hl=en&amp;ie=UTF-8&amp;u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.policia.es%2Fprensa%2F20130927_1.html">"The National Police completes the second phase of the operation "Ransomware"<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 October</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+National+Police+completes+the+second+phase+of+the+operation+%22Ransomware%22&amp;rft.pub=El+Cuerpo+Nacional+de+Polic%C3%ADa&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ftranslate.google.com%2Ftranslate%3Fsl%3Des%26tl%3Den%26js%3Dn%26prev%3D_t%26hl%3Den%26ie%3DUTF-8%26u%3Dhttp%253A%252F%252Fwww.policia.es%252Fprensa%252F20130927_1.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-71">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFSampson2013" class="citation web cs1">Sampson, Tim (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dailydot.com/business/11-bitcoins-seized-government-dea/">"U.S. government makes its first-ever Bitcoin seizure"</a>. <li id="cite_note-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-86">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFNatasha_Lomas2013" class="citation web cs1">Natasha Lomas (18 November 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://techcrunch.com/2013/11/18/btc-china-series-a/">"As Chinese Investors Pile Into Bitcoin, China's Oldest Exchange, BTC China, Raises $5M From Lightspeed"</a>. <li id="cite_note-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-102">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFFlacy2014" class="citation web cs1">Flacy, Mike (19 July 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.digitaltrends.com/web/dell-newegg-start-accepting-bitcoin-payment/#!bv9oFm">"Dell, Newegg Start Accepting Bitcoin as Payment"</a>. <li id="cite_note-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-103">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFCallawayGreebelMoriarityXethalis" class="citation news cs1">Callaway, Claudia; Greebel, Evan; Moriarity, Kathleen; Xethalis, Gregory; Kim, Diana. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.natlawreview.com/article/first-bitcoin-swap-proposed">"First Bitcoin Swap Proposed"</a>. <i>The National Law Review</i>. Katten Muchin Rosenman LLP<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 September</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+National+Law+Review&amp;rft.atitle=First+Bitcoin+Swap+Proposed&amp;rft.aulast=Callaway&amp;rft.aufirst=Claudia&amp;rft.au=Greebel%2C+Evan&amp;rft.au=Moriarity%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.au=Xethalis%2C+Gregory&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Diana&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.natlawreview.com%2Farticle%2Ffirst-bitcoin-swap-proposed&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-106">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFPaul_Vigna2014" class="citation news cs1">Paul Vigna (18 February 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2014/02/18/bitbeat-mt-goxs-pyrrhic-victory/">"BitBeat: Mt. Gox's Pyrrhic Victory"</a>. <i>Money Beat</i>. The Wall Street Journal. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141006143115/http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2014/02/18/bitbeat-mt-goxs-pyrrhic-victory/">Archived</a> from the original on 6 October 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 September</span> 2014</span>. <q>'Ode to Satoshi' is a bluegrass-style song with an old-timey feel that mixes references to Satoshi Nakamoto and blockchains (and, ahem, 'the fall of old Mt. Gox') with mandolin-picking and harmonicas.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Money+Beat&amp;rft.atitle=BitBeat%3A+Mt.+Gox%27s+Pyrrhic+Victory&amp;rft.date=2014-02-18&amp;rft.au=Paul+Vigna&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fblogs.wsj.com%2Fmoneybeat%2F2014%2F02%2F18%2Fbitbeat-mt-goxs-pyrrhic-victory%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-116">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170107101512/https://support.bidorbuy.co.za/index.php?%2FKnowledgebase%2FArticle%2FView%2F210%2F0%2Factivating-and-using-bitcoin-as-a-payment-option">"Activating and Using Bitcoin as a Payment Option"</a>. <li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFTascaLiuHayes2016" class="citation cs2">Tasca, Paolo; Liu, Shaowen; Hayes, Adam (1 July 2016), <i>The Evolution of the Bitcoin Economy: Extracting and Analyzing the Network of Payment Relationships</i>, p.&#160;36, <a href="/wiki/SSRN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="SSRN (identifier)">SSRN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2808762">2808762</a>, <q>By November, 2013, the amount of inflows attributable to ”sin” entities had shrunk significantly to just 3% or less of total transactions.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Evolution+of+the+Bitcoin+Economy%3A+Extracting+and+Analyzing+the+Network+of+Payment+Relationships&amp;rft.pages=36&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fpapers.ssrn.com%2Fsol3%2Fpapers.cfm%3Fabstract_id%3D2808762%23id-name%3DSSRN&amp;rft.aulast=Tasca&amp;rft.aufirst=Paolo&amp;rft.au=Liu%2C+Shaowen&amp;rft.au=Hayes%2C+Adam&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-bitfinexheist-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-bitfinexheist_118-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFCoppola2016" class="citation news cs1">Coppola, Frances (6 August 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160807023213/http://www.forbes.com/sites/francescoppola/2016/08/06/theft-and-mayhem-in-the-bitcoin-world/#3adc93c251ae">"Theft And Mayhem In The Bitcoin World"</a>. <i>Forbes</i>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-119">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.sbb.ch/en/station-services/at-the-station/services-from-the-ticket-machine/bitcoin.html">"SBB: Make quick and easy purchases with Bitcoin"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 March</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=SBB%3A+Make+quick+and+easy+purchases+with+Bitcoin.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.sbb.ch%2Fen%2Fstation-services%2Fat-the-station%2Fservices-from-the-ticket-machine%2Fbitcoin.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-120">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170110015417/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20170109/k10010833281000.html">"ビットコイン 利用可能店舗が１年で４．６倍に"</a>. 9 January 2017. <li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://medium.com/@spair/the-bitcoin-fee-market-4df1857d12b7">"The Bitcoin Fee Market"</a>. 7 March 2017. <q>our transaction growth of nearly 3x [...] Many of the businesses we’ve signed up over the years have started using BitPay for B2B supply chain payments.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=The+Bitcoin+Fee+Market&amp;rft.date=2017-03-07&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40spair%2Fthe-bitcoin-fee-market-4df1857d12b7&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Atlantic1-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Atlantic1_154-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFEstes2013" class="citation web cs1">Estes, Adam (28 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.theatlanticwire.com/business/2013/03/bitcoin-now-billion-dollar-industry/63667/">"Bitcoin is now a billion dollar industry"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131011011041/http://www.theatlanticwire.com/business/2013/03/bitcoin-now-billion-dollar-industry/63667/">Archived</a> from the original on 11 October 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-171">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFKelly2017" class="citation news cs1">Kelly, Jemima (15 December 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-markets-bitcoin/bitcoin-hits-new-record-high-as-warnings-grow-louder-idUSKBN1E919T">"Bitcoin hits new record high as warnings grow louder"</a>. <i>Reuters</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://fortune.com/2017/12/17/bitcoin-record-high-short-of-20000/">"Bitcoin Hits a New Record High, But Stops Short of $20,000"</a>. <i>Fortune</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Forbes1-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Forbes1_204-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFLee2013" class="citation news cs1">Lee, Timothy (19 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/timothylee/2013/03/19/new-money-laundering-guidelines-are-a-positive-sign-for-bitcoin/">"New Money Laundering Guidelines Are A Positive Sign For Bitcoin"</a>. <i>Forbes</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131019052723/http://www.forbes.com/sites/timothylee/2013/03/19/new-money-laundering-guidelines-are-a-positive-sign-for-bitcoin/">Archived</a> from the original on 19 October 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-JapanTimes-205"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-JapanTimes_205-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFFaiolaFarnam2013" class="citation news cs1">Faiola, Anthony; Farnam, T.W. (4 April 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195258/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-04-04/world/38280106_1_bitcoin-satoshi-nakamoto-monetary-policy">"The rise of the bitcoin: Virtual gold or cyber-bubble?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-ECBank201210-206"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ECBank201210_206-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ecb.int/pub/pdf/other/virtualcurrencyschemes201210en.pdf">"Virtual Currency Schemes"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. European Central Bank. October 2012. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130228022032/http://www.ecb.int/pub/pdf/other/virtualcurrencyschemes201210en.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 28 February 2013.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Virtual+Currency+Schemes&amp;rft.pub=European+Central+Bank&amp;rft.date=2012-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ecb.int%2Fpub%2Fpdf%2Fother%2Fvirtualcurrencyschemes201210en.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-foxnews1-207"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-foxnews1_207-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2013/04/11/bitcoin-electronic-cash-beloved-by-hackers/">"Bitcoin, the nationless electronic cash beloved by hackers, bursts into financial mainstream"</a>. <i>Fox News</i>. 11 April 2013. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131107093313/http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2013/04/11/bitcoin-electronic-cash-beloved-by-hackers/">Archived</a> from the original on 7 November 2013.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Fox+News&amp;rft.atitle=Bitcoin%2C+the+nationless+electronic+cash+beloved+by+hackers%2C+bursts+into+financial+mainstream&amp;rft.date=2013-04-11&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.foxnews.com%2Ftech%2F2013%2F04%2F11%2Fbitcoin-electronic-cash-beloved-by-hackers%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span>. <li id="cite_note-mick-220"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-mick_220-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-mick_220-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFMick2011" class="citation web cs1">Mick, Jason (19 June 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130422131626/http://www.dailytech.com/Inside+the+MegaHack+of+Bitcoin+the+Full+Story/article21942.htm">"Inside the Mega-Hack of Bitcoin: the Full Story"</a>. <a href="/wiki/DailyTech" title="DailyTech">DailyTech</a>. <li id="cite_note-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-221">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lee, Timothy B. (19 June 2011) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/06/bitcoin-price-plummets-on-compromised-exchange.ars">"Bitcoin prices plummet on hacked exchange"</a>. 19 June 2011. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120410034832/http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/06/bitcoin-price-plummets-on-compromised-exchange.ars">Archived</a> from the original on 10 April 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 June</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Bitcoin+prices+plummet+on+hacked+exchange&amp;rft.date=2011-06-19&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farstechnica.com%2Ftech-policy%2Fnews%2F2011%2F06%2Fbitcoin-price-plummets-on-compromised-exchange.ars&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span>, Ars Technica</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-222">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Karpeles, Mark (20 June 2011) <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://support.mtgox.com/entries/20208066-huge-bitcoin-sell-off-due-to-a-compromised-account-rollback">Huge Bitcoin sell off due to a compromised account&#160;– rollback</a>, Mt.Gox Support <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5zZUX7u5V?url=http://support.mtgox.com/entries/20208066-huge-bitcoin-sell-off-due-to-a-compromised-account-rollback">Archived</a> 20 June 2011 at <a href="/wiki/WebCite" title="WebCite">WebCite</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-cutler13insta-236"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cutler13insta_236-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cutler13insta_236-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFCutler2013" class="citation web cs1">Cutler, Kim-Mai (3 April 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://techcrunch.com/2013/04/03/bitcoin-instawallet/">"Another Bitcoin Wallet Service, Instawallet, Suffers Attack, Shuts Down Until Further Notice"</a>. <a href="/wiki/TechCrunch" title="TechCrunch">TechCrunch</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140331085500/http://techcrunch.com/2013/04/03/bitcoin-instawallet/">Archived</a> from the original on 31 March 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 April</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Another+Bitcoin+Wallet+Service%2C+Instawallet%2C+Suffers+Attack%2C+Shuts+Down+Until+Further+Notice&amp;rft.pub=TechCrunch&amp;rft.date=2013-04-03&amp;rft.aulast=Cutler&amp;rft.aufirst=Kim-Mai&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ftechcrunch.com%2F2013%2F04%2F03%2Fbitcoin-instawallet%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-237"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-237">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://blockchain.info/tx/5c265c7f63176a07d8c1a90c336e8faac133e69b95eb29e69026377781ebdd1e">"Transaction details for bitcoins stolen from Instawallet"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131019155836/http://blockchain.info/tx/5c265c7f63176a07d8c1a90c336e8faac133e69b95eb29e69026377781ebdd1e">Archived</a> from the original on 19 October 2013.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Transaction+details+for+bitcoins+stolen+from+Instawallet&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fblockchain.info%2Ftx%2F5c265c7f63176a07d8c1a90c336e8faac133e69b95eb29e69026377781ebdd1e&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+bitcoin" class="Z3988"></span>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-TheRegister20130812-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-TheRegister20130812_238-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974"/><cite id="CITEREFChirgwin2013" class="citation web cs1">Chirgwin, Richard (12 August 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/6IwX8oDIN?url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/08/12/android_bug_batters_bitcoin_wallets/">"Android bug batters Bitcoin wallets / Old flaw, new problem"</a>. <i>The Register</i>.
